top_comment.text:
This might be a weird question but, how do you Harness train a cat so they 
can be a walking partner﻿
top_comment.author: Elley Logan

comments.text:
What I did with my kitty was to first purchase a leash and a figure 8 
harness. They are specially designed for cats because if you attach a dog 
harness or to their collar, your kitty can easily slip out. Next, I put the 
figure 8 harness on her everyday for a short period of time (without the 
leash) so she could get used to it. Then, I let her drag the leash around 
without me holding on to her. Finally, I held the leash and walked her 
around the neighborhood. Most cats don't follow you, but rather smell the 
fauna. This is okay, and they will get used to being "walked" and will 
enjoy the companionship of the outdoors.
comments.author: Kendra Wuhoo

top_comment.text: How do I get my cat to go outside and not run away﻿
top_comment.author: Harry McCauley

comments.text:
Depending on your location it can be dangerous to let your cat out. The 
best way would be to build a 'catio'- an outdoor enclosure for your cat. 
However that can be expensive and sometimes impossible depending on zoning 
issues.I would suggest purchasing a cat harness and leash, and gently 
training your cat to learn to wear it inside, then start taking him/her out 
for a few minutes at the time until the cat is comfortable outside on the 
harness... then just take him out once or twice a day and let him explore 
that way. If you ever feel comfortable enough to let him off the leash make 
sure he has a collar and name tag incase he gets lost- but remember, if you 
let him loose then there's always a chance he will end up in the road, in 
the yard with an unfriendly dog, picked up by a stranger, in a cat fight, 
etc. There's always risk with letting your cat outside unsupervised.
comments.author: CapnSavvy

top_comment.text: #TeamCatMojoBooks on cat behavior I recommend: http://buff.ly/1rLB7aW﻿
top_comment.author: Jackson Galaxy

comments.text:
I suggest "Cat Watching" and "Cat Lore" by Desmond Morris, amazing books 
about cat behavior!
comments.author: Nicole Anne Collet

comments.text:
I'm a first time cat owner to 2 kittens and I just wanted to say thank you 
for your VERY informative videos. You've helped me figure out a lot about 
my new fellow feline family members. Thanks again!
comments.author: Ace Boog1e (Ham Cam)

comments.text:
What do you think about the cats of Scottish Fold breed? Whether their ears 
which are naturally constantly pressed to the head mean aggression for 
other cats?
comments.author: Julia Winter

captions.text: Team cat mojo, here we go.
Cat Cave version 2.0.

I'm going to take you around
here, going to show you
what's up.
Let's take catified.
Go.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[PLAYING GUITAR]
We are now relocated in house.

And the Cat Cave is
now open for business.

So what I'm going
to do today, going
to take you around the Cat Cave.

By the way, this holds a very
special place in the Cat Cave.

This here is a guitar
custom made by me

and presented to me on the
set of My Cat From Hell

by a good guy named Mike
at Riverstone Guitars.

And I got to tell you
something, the best

guitar I've ever
laid my hands on.

It wouldn't be a Cat Cave if
we didn't have cat books here.
And these are not just for show.

These are things I refer to all
the time, "The Natural Cat,"

"The New Natural Cat,"
Anitra Frazier, love her.
This is an amazing book.

This book right here,
dry like white toast.

But I got to tell
you, this study

that Paul Leyhausen did
really revolutionized the way

we take a look at
cats by looking

at feral colonies
and their behavior.

Gotta love this one too,
"The Cat Who Cried for Help,"
my friend Nick Dodman here.

This is a fantastic
book in terms

of day to day health and
upkeep and maintenance

and just a really great
life for your cat.

This is also wonderful,
"Cat Behavior."
This is a great beginning book.

If you don't know anything
about cat behavior,
this is a great place to start.

Then we have Jeffrey
Mason's book,

"The Nine Emotional
Lives of Cats."

In order to solve problems
in your home with your cats,

it's first of all
important to acknowledge

the depth of their
emotional life.

This is a great place to
start, this book right here.

Now, let's take a look at
the bigger, the zeitgeist,
that is the Cat Cave.
So let's take a big shot here.

I know you guys have seen this
portrait of Benny back here,

but Benny my boy that we
wrote "Cat Daddy" about.
This guitar here, really funny.

At one point you guys,
if you've read my book--

which you should read my book--
you would that at one point
I weighed 400 pounds.

I was playing this
guitar, and I saw

a picture of me
playing it on stage.

And it looked like a ukulele
because I was such a big guy.

So I actually went on
eBay, saw this guitar,
said, OK, it's a big guitar.

I put one bid on the damn thing
and got saddled with the bill.
But I do love that guitar.

Up here you'll
see-- I don't know

if you guys remember
the episode with Tony

the cat, the one
who would sexually

assault a stuffed
animal-- that's

Ninja Tony, which I had
Betty, his person, make.

And I love Ninja
Tony, so he's still
up there filled with catnip.

Right next door to that,
you see this picture

from Susan Weingarten,
a good friend of mine.

That is, to me, one of those
things that really gives you
the essence of cat.

Here my friend Bob Walker
and Francis Mooney,

this was a kind
of a seminal book
when it came to catification.

If you guys don't have
"The Cat's House,"

it's going to be hard to find
this teeny little version.

But you can find
the big version.

And when you start
catifying, start there.

And of course, with my
book, "Catification,"

coming out to a bookstore
near you in October.

Anyway there's-- oh,
well hi, Peeshee.

And this is what makes the Cat
Cave the Cat Cave now, folks.

But now we get to have
cats in the Cat Cave.
I couldn't be happier right now.
This completes the vibe.

We are catifying
my world right now.
That's about it.

In the meantime, you want to
talk to me about all things

catification, or mojo-ish,
or anything like that,
you know where to find me.

You know that you can go
to Twitter, or Facebook,

or Instagram, or Google,
or, like I've always said,

standing on line
at the Whole Foods.
Whatever it is, you can find me.

And you can get answers
to the questions
that you might have about cats.

All right, until next time,
folks, all light of love.
All mojo to you.
Love you.
[PLAYING GUITAR AND SINGING]
